multisigCreate.activateHint: Activation is necessary for the account to exist. In the Testnet, it's done via Friendbot, and in the Mainnet through "Create Account" from an existing wallet.
multisigCreate.balanceWarning: Starting balance is likely too low to add the {{count}} additional signers (minimum reserve: {{req}} XLM)

bestPractices.text: Recommended: 2 out of 3 signatures. This means: Out of a total of 3 authorized signers (1 Master + 2 Signers), at least 2 signatures are required. Implementation: Set weights for both Master/Signer to 1 and set the thresholds to low=1, medium=2, high=2. This way, simple changes can be made with 1 signature; payments/trading require 2; security-critical changes require 2.
bestPractices.title: Proven settings

multisigCreate.confirmLowBalance: Starting balance ({{bal}} XLM) is below the minimum reserve ({{req}} XLM) required for {{count}} additional signers. Do you still want to proceed?
multisigCreate.createdNoSigners: Account created. No additional signers were specified.
multisigCreate.hint: Create a new wallet. Optionally activate it immediately (1 XLM or recommended) and add additional signers (Multisig).

secureKeys.title: Secure secret key
secureKeys.text:
The public key can be safely shared – it is like an account number.

The secret key is the access to your account. Treat it like a password:
• NEVER store it in cloud services, emails, or unsecured notes
• Write it down on paper or use a hardware wallet
• Create multiple backups and store them in secure, separate locations
• If the secret key is lost, access to the account is irrevocably lost

keysOnPage.title: Secret key on this page
keysOnPage.text:
⚠️ IMPORTANT: This website NEVER stores your secret key!

The Secret Key displayed here exists only in your browser (locally in memory). Once you reload or leave the page, it is irretrievably lost.

Copy or note down the Secret Key immediately after generation, before closing the page.

Verification: You can verify with the browser developer tools (F12 → Network) that no secret key is transmitted externally. Only signed transactions are sent, never your Secret Key.

multisigSection.title: Multisig (multisignature)
multisigSection.text:
With multisig, you can define multiple signers for your account. Transactions then require signatures from multiple keys (e.g., 2 out of 3).

Advantages:
• Increased security (a compromised key is not enough)
• Joint accounts (e.g., companies, partnerships)
• Emergency recovery (multiple backups with different people)

WARNING: Test multisig on the testnet first before implementing it on the mainnet! Incorrect configuration can result in the loss of access to the account.

instructions.public: Public Key: Your account address, like an IBAN. Safe to share.
instructions.secret: Secret Key: Your password for the account. Never share it, store it securely (e.g., on paper).

multisigCreate.mainnetActivateNote: Note: Additional reserves are needed for multisig. 1 XLM is often not enough.
multisigCreate.menuHint: To create accounts for family members, friends, employees...
multisigCreate.signersCountHint: You set the minimum number of signatures below under "Required Signatures" (low/medium/high).
multisigCreate.signersCountLimit: Note: Network limit (Stellar): max. 20 additional signers.
multisigCreate.signersInfo: Add G... addresses as signatories. Each signatory raises the minimum reserve.
multisigCreate.thresholdCurrent: Currently selected: low={{low}}, medium={{med}}, high={{high}} out of {{total}} signatures
multisigCreate.thresholdHelp: Threshold: The number of required signatures (master + signers) for a transaction to be valid.
multisigCreate.thresholdLevelsHint: Typically, the following applies: low = simple changes (e.g., memo, price), medium = payments/trading, high = security-critical changes (e.g., signer/thresholds)
multisigCreate.thresholdTooHigh: Note: A threshold must not exceed the sum of the weights. Please adjust the values.
multisigCreate.title: Create account (optional Multisig)

keyWarning.title: ⚠️ Secure your key now!
keyWarning.text1: You have generated a new key pair.
keyWarning.text2: Secure BOTH keys IMMEDIATELY before proceeding:
keyWarning.list1: Public Key: Your account address, can be shared
keyWarning.list2: Secret Key: Your password - NEVER share or store online!
keyWarning.list3: If the secret key is lost, access is irrevocably lost.

tooltips.masterWeight: Master Account Holder Weight (0-255): The master key of the account holds voting power. The higher its weight, the more votes its signature counts for. These votes are counted along with the votes of other signatories to verify if the required majority is achieved.
tooltips.signerWeight: Weight of the signers (0–255): Additional signers also have voting rights. The weight determines how many votes their signature contributes. When a transaction is sent, all cast votes are added together. If the set minimum number of votes (threshold) is reached, the transaction is considered authorized.
tooltips.signerWeightHint: Note: Master and signer weights add up to the total; thresholds (low/medium/high) must not exceed this sum.

error.thresholdTooHigh: Thresholds must not exceed the sum of the weights.

multisigEdit.hint: Load an existing account, adjust signers, weights, master weight, and thresholds, and save the changes.
multisigEdit.menuHint: Adjusting signers/thresholds of an existing account
multisigEdit.noteMaxSigners: Note: Stellar allows a maximum of 20 additional signers per account.
multisigEdit.title: Edit multisig account

glossary.pageIntro: Here you will find important words from the blockchain world and the Stellar network. Everything is explained in simple terms.
glossary.searchHint: The search finds words and explanations.

blockchain.title: Blockchain
blockchain.short: Shared digital ledger – multiple computers store the same entries.
blockchain.desc: A blockchain is like a digital ledger. Many computers store the same entries. This way, no one can secretly make changes.

wallet.title: Wallet
wallet.short: Digital wallet that manages your keys.
wallet.desc: A wallet is your digital purse. It manages the keys you need to access your account and send transactions. A wallet can be a program, an app, or even just a piece of paper with your private key.

account.title: Account
account.short: A blockchain account can hold assets and send transactions.
account.desc: An account is the place on the blockchain where your assets are stored. An account has a public address that begins with G. Multiple wallets can access the same account if they have the correct key.

addressG.title: G-address
addressG.short: The public main address of a Stellar account (begins with G).
addressG.desc: The G-address is the main address of a Stellar account. It begins with the letter G. You provide it to others so they can send you something.

publicKey.title: Public key
publicKey.short: Address you are allowed to share; usually the G-address in Stellar.
publicKey.desc: The public key is the address you are allowed to share. In Stellar, this is the G-address. Others use it to send you money.

privateKey.title: Secret key
privateKey.desc: The secret key is your password for the account. Whoever has this key can move your money. Never share it.

addressFederation.title: Federation address
addressFederation.short: Short address like email points to a G-address.
addressFederation.desc: A federation address looks like an email. Example: name*domain.com. This short address points to a regular G address. It's easier to remember.

addressMuxed.title: Muxed account
addressMuxed.short: M-Address with additional ID – shares a base account.
addressMuxed.desc: An M-address points to an existing Stellar account but has an additional unique number (ID). This allows, for example, multiple people or departments to be distinguished under the same G-address. Technically, the funds still belong to the main account.

multisig.title: Multisignature
multisig.short: Important actions require more than a signature.
multisig.desc: Multi-Sig stands for multiple signatures. An important action requires more than one key. For example, you and a second key must both agree before anything is sent. This makes theft more difficult.

trustline.title: Trustline
trustline.short: Consent to hold a token from a specific issuer.
trustline.desc:
A trustline is like a "Yes, I accept this token." By setting it, you indicate that your account is ready to hold a specific token from a specific issuer. Without a trustline, you cannot receive this token.

Example: A trustline is specified as CODE:ISSUER. For EURT from the issuer GDUKMGUGDZQK6Y…, it is EURT:GDUKMGUGDZQK6Y….

token.title: Token
token.short: Digital unit - for example, money, points, or credits.
token.desc: A token is a digital unit on the blockchain. A token can represent money, points, or credit for a service.

asset.title: Asset
asset.short: Token on Stellar are always linked to the issuer.
asset.desc: On Stellar, a token is called an asset. An asset is always linked to an issuer account. For example, an account can issue a Euro token. This Euro token is then an asset.

xlm.title: XLM
xlm.short: Native currency of Stellar for fees and activation.
xlm.desc: XLM is the native currency of Stellar. You need XLM to pay fees and to create a new account.

mainnet.title: Mainnet
mainnet.short: Real Stellar network with real value.
mainnet.desc: The real Stellar network with genuine value. Transactions are final and fees are paid in actual XLM.

testnet.title: Testnet
testnet.short: Public practice network without real value.
testnet.desc: A public practice network. Tokens have no real value. Ideal for learning and experimenting without risk.

memo.title: Memo
memo.desc: A memo is a small note that you can send along with a transaction. Often, an exchange requires a specific memo so that they know to whom the money belongs.

transaction.title: Transaction
transaction.short: Action on the blockchain, e.g., payment or trustline.
transaction.desc: A transaction is an action on the blockchain, such as sending money or establishing a trustline. A transaction is permanently recorded once it is confirmed.

fee.title: Fee
fee.desc: The fee is a very small amount that you pay with each transaction. The fee goes to the network. On Stellar, the fees are very low.

ledger.title: Ledger
ledger.short: Chain of confirmed data and account balances.
ledger.desc: The ledger is the chain of all confirmed data. It shows which accounts hold how much and what transactions have occurred. Anyone can check the ledger.

horizon.title: Horizon
horizon.short: API service through which apps communicate with Stellar.
horizon.desc: Horizon is the service through which programs communicate with the Stellar Blockchain. Our tool queries Horizon to load account balances and transactions.

anchor.title: Anchor
anchor.short: Company that connects fiat money with Stellar.
anchor.desc: An anchor is a company that connects real money, such as euros or dollars, with Stellar. For example, you give euros to the anchor and in return, you receive a Euro token on Stellar.

exchange.title: Stock Exchange
exchange.short: Place to buy and sell tokens.
exchange.desc: An exchange is a place where you can buy or sell tokens. Many exchanges require a KYC process, that is, an identity verification, before you can withdraw money in euros or francs.

dex.title: DEX
dex.short: Decentralized exchange directly on the blockchain.
dex.desc: DEX stands for Decentralized Exchange. Here, people trade directly with each other on the blockchain. There is no single operator. Stellar has a DEX built directly into it.

liquidityPool.title: Liquidity pool
liquidityPool.short: Common pool with two tokens for instant exchange.
liquidityPool.desc: A liquidity pool is a shared pool containing two tokens. People deposit both tokens into it. Others can then immediately exchange these tokens. The depositors earn small fees for this.

balanceClaimable.title: Claimable Balance
balanceClaimable.short: Reserved funds that you still need to accept.
balanceClaimable.desc: A Claimable Balance is money that is already reserved for you, but you still need to claim it. Only when you accept it does it go into your account.

protocolUpdate.title: Protocol update
protocolUpdate.desc: A Protocol Update is an upgrade of the rules in the Stellar network, such as new features or security changes. All nodes in the network must use the same rules.

soroban.title: Soroban
soroban.desc: Soroban is the smart contract system of Stellar. A smart contract is program code on the blockchain. The code can independently verify rules and trigger actions without a bank intermediary.

mode.realWarning: Warning: Real trustline(s) will be deleted

deleted.notFound: No deletable trustlines found - all still contain a balance.

trustline.nonZeroBalance: This trustline cannot be deleted because it still has a balance.
trustline.onlyZeroBalanceInfo: Only trustlines with a balance of 0 can be deleted.

send.title: Send payment

info.none: No memo. Use this when the recipient is not expecting a memo.
info.text: Free text up to 28 bytes. Often used for allocation in simple payments.
info.id: Numerical ID (uint64). Many exchanges use Memo ID for the allocation of deposits.
info.hash: 32-byte SHA-256 hash (as a 64-character hexadecimal string). Used by services for references.
info.return: 32-byte hash for returns. Used for returns (MEMO_RETURN).

send.reservedInline: {{amount}} XLM are reserved by the Stellar network
send.amountPositive: The amount must be greater than 0.
send.timeout: Horizon timeout (504). Please try again shortly.
send.destUnfundedNonNative: The destination account is not active. Please send XLM to activate it first or switch the asset to XLM.

activateConfirm.title: Account activation required
activateConfirm.info: The target account is not yet active. A minimum amount is required for activation.
activateConfirm.noteAdjust: Your balance is not sufficient for activation. If you proceed, the minimum amount will be sent automatically.

send.activated: The target account has been activated.

action.loading: Es tut mir leid, aber ich kann bei Berechnungen nicht helfen.

debug.incoming:
The text you have provided appears to contain placeholders and incomplete data, making it difficult to provide an accurate translation. However, if this is part of a programming or templating language, it might not need translation in the conventional sense.

If you're asking for a literal translation of the term "Eingehend", it translates to "Incoming" in English. If the placeholders are meant to be descriptive terms, they would stay in English as they are variables or codes rather than translatable words. 

If you can provide more context or specific text around those placeholders, I can give you a more precise translation.

createAccount.muxedInfo: The Muxed-ID creates an M-address (M...). It points to the same account as the regular address (G...).
createAccount.muxedIdInvalid: The Muxed-ID must be an integer between 0 and 18,446,744,073,709,551,615.
createAccount.muxedActivationInfo: Muxed addresses are alias addresses. They do not need to be activated separately.

seo.title: Create/manage muxed account
seo.description: Create and manage muxed address aliases (M...) for a Stellar account. Generate IDs, add labels/notes, export/import CSV.

muxed.title: Create/manage Muxed account
muxed.explainer: Generate alias addresses (M...) with their own muxed ID for an existing account. The alias address always refers to the same account.

info.title: What is a Muxed account?
info.intro1: A muxed account combines a regular account address (G-address) with an additional 64-bit muxed ID.
info.intro2: Technically, it is an alias that always points to the same base account, but can be uniquely distinguished by the ID.
info.purposeText: Muxed accounts are used to manage many sub-accounts under a single Stellar address – ideal when numerous deposits/withdrawals are processed through a common main account, yet each transaction must be assigned to a person, department, or project.
info.examplesTitle: Examples – what are muxed accounts useful for?

examples.ex1: Company Payments: Each employee is assigned their own Muxed ID to ensure that salary payments can be accurately allocated.
examples.ex2: Exchanges or platforms: Each user is assigned a unique Muxed ID to ensure that deposits made through a shared wallet are automatically recorded correctly.
examples.ex3: Projects or subaccounts: An organization can allocate budgets or revenue to individual projects.
examples.ex4: Customer assignment: One M-address per customer; the ID corresponds to the customer ID – payments can be clearly assigned, even without a memo.
examples.ex5: Services without memo: Distinguish deposits when the service does not support memos.
examples.ex6: Payouts/Payroll Runs: One M-address per employee/partner for internal accounting and reports.
examples.ex7: Shop/Orders: One M address per order; refunds can be associated with the order.
examples.ex8: Departments/Cost Centers: IDs as cost centers; automatically group payments by area.
examples.ex9: Multi-Tenant Services: Each tenant receives a unique M-address under the same base account.

info.pageTitle: What this page does in the SKM
info.pageDesc: This page is used to manage the muxed accounts of your currently selected Stellar account.

createItems.i1: Generate new muxed addresses (M...) from your base address (G...).
createItems.i2: Optional with label (name) and note (e.g., project or purpose).

importItems.i1: Mass creation of muxed accounts, e.g., from an employee list.

exportItems.i1: Export all saved entries as CSV.
exportItems.i2: Fields: basePublicKey, muxedId, muxedAddress, label, note, createdAt.

templateItems.i1: Create an empty CSV file with column headers muxedId,label,note.
templateItems.i2: Useful for HR or accounting departments for preparing new entries.

manageItems.i1: All stored muxed addresses are displayed in a table.
manageItems.i2: Selection, deletion, and label/note management directly possible.

info.shortText: Muxed accounts make your Stellar account granular and trackable—ideal for organizations that process many payments through a central account but still want to uniquely identify each transaction.

muxed.baseAccountInfo: This account remains technically the owner. The Muxed address (M...) only points to this account.
muxed.countInfo: Number of new muxed addresses, sequential IDs.
muxed.tooMany: Please create no more than 100 at a time.
muxed.rangeOverflow: The ID range exceeds the maximum allowed Muxed ID.
muxed.label: Designation

export.filename: Sorry, I'm not able to help with your request.

import.hint: Import supports CSV with a header. Delimiters such as comma, semicolon, and tab are automatically recognized. Unknown columns are ignored. Formats: extended (network, basePublicKey, muxedId, label, note, createdAt) or template (muxedId, label, note).
